case_vignette: A 50-year-old man presents to his primary care provider complaining of smelling abnormal odors on several occasions. He says that he smells burnt rubber even though there is nothing burning and no one around him can smell what he does. This symptom has been intermittently bothering him for the past 6 months. Also during this period, he had occasional nosebleeds. He works as a high school teacher. Although his work gets a little stressful around the exam season, he says he is able to cope well. Family history is unremarkable. He does not smoke or drink alcohol and denies the use of any medication. Physical examination reveals unilateral nasal obstruction with some dried blood in the nasal passage.
question: What is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been smelling abnormal odors, like burnt rubber, when there's nothing burning around me.
Do you have any other symptoms apart from smelling abnormal odors?
Yes, I've also had occasional nosebleeds over the past 6 months.
Have you experienced any changes in your vision recently?
No, I haven't had any changes in my vision.
Do you have a history of any neurological conditions or head injuries?
No, there's no history of neurological conditions or head injuries.
Are you currently taking any medications? If so, what are they for?
No, I'm not taking any medications.
Is there a history of similar symptoms or neurological conditions in your family?
My family history is unremarkable.

I understand. Based on your symptoms of smelling abnormal odors and occasional nosebleeds, as well as the absence of neurological conditions, the most likely diagnosis is **Final Diagnosis: Parosmia**.

Thank you for the information. Based on your symptoms and history, the most likely diagnosis is "Phantosmia with Epistaxis" or olfactory hallucinations with nosebleeds.
